ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Fundamentals of the design process in a mechanical engineering environment.
Brainstorming and product design principles, basic Arduino
design
I further developed my knowledge about design and approaches to it.
I gained valuable experience in SolidWorks, Arduino code, and the Yale machine shops.

honestly nothing really. this class was pretty terrible. we didn't learn much in this course. the last week was super stressful having to create a complete ball and beam sensor, first design it, then build it, then wire it then code with it with literally no instruction on how to to do so from the entire semester. class time was filled with tbh nothing like literally nothing we wouldn't talk about anything pertaining to anything really. and we definitely didn't really review mechanical design. pretty awful class.
Basic design with solid works
Literally nothing. The very few skills I acquired were from Youtube videos
Much was learned about the design cycle of brainstorming, prototyping, testing, and repeate until you get the desired product.
Communication could be improved a bit, but Professor Freeman is a great Professor. Had a wonderful time.  Good semester, thank you.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is heavily focused on the concept of the mechanical design process, which I believe to be a strength. The class does not focus as much on the craft. You get what you give for this class.
Weaknesses: Not very organized.

Strengths - Prof Freeman is very knowledgeable and clearly passionate about engineering. The final project was a cool idea. We didn't do anything in lecture. 
Weaknesses - He didn't translate his knowledge into formats that we could learn from. If you have little experience with actually building things out of wood and screws or coding with Arduino, the final project is a headache and a half. We didn't do anything in lecture.
cool ideas for projects, but we weren't able to actually do many projects

The course was pretty disorganized, the syllabus was not really followed and the professor didnt seem to plan lectures.  I would say that a strength to this course Was that it forced me to teach myself. A lot of this course was me teaching myself because the professor didnt teach us it. We had to code in arduino and we didnt learn how to code in arduino. The solid works that we learned was doing the built in solid works tutorials. On the syllabus it said we were supposed to get some experience in the machine shop machining a candlestick but that was cut out of the syllabus which was unfortunate because that is something that should be done in meng 185.
Instead of one project ramping up only in the final two weeks, the course should have two or three (possibly slightly less complex) projects throughout the semester.

the instructor was quite awful. literally did not learn a single thing. a single thing. im not even sure there was a syllabus or like a weekly agenda. had no test no quizzes no anything which is fine but then got to the final project, and didn't even know how to hammer a screw into a board much less build a ball and beam sensor.
I believe that I did not actually learn anything, except for my own effort with watching basic tutorials for solid works

The course was not very organized, with class being cancelled a lot with and without warning and actual class time not providing much valuable information for our final project. The strength was actual lab time with the ULAs.

I would like to have more diverse class projects and topics rather than focusing on one big project. While the project was very engaging and help build many aspects of design, I would have liked to have some days that didn't just focus on the project.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely. This is a great introduction to what mechanical engineering is as a field and what the design process should look like.
The class was really easy because there were very few assignments, but it was also pretty boring and felt like a bit of a waste of time.

Seems like a great course in theory, but Prof Freeman was not organized at all. I couldn't tell you a single thing I learned this semester. We didn't have any lectures, homework assignments, or exams, which seems nice... but that meant our final grade was just based on vibes. I know this was his first time teaching the class, so he wasn't sure exactly how to go about it, but the class was not well organized to facilitate student learning. The syllabus wasn't posted until two weeks after add/drop period, and we didn't follow it at all. Lab didn't start until halfway through the semester. We had one project for the whole semester (a ball and beam balance, super cool!) but we didn't actually get the materials to build it until the last week of classes. This meant the whole device had to be built and coded during reading period, which was annoying since we didn't do anything the whole semester. If you need this course for the MechE major, it will probably be an easy A. If you're taking it to learn new skills as a non-MechE major, take it with a different professor.
course seems to be different every year due to different professors. cool project based class
Yes, despite the necessity of course improvements, it was a productive class for aspiring engineers even in its current state.
no. you won't learn anything. take something else. or at least with this instructor.
The way that I experienced it, no I do not.
If you're taking this it's probably because it is required for your major, but if you are just wanting to explore mechanical design there are probably better ways to do that than taking this course.

Not in its current form. I learned nothing in that class. We did absolutely nothing for the entire semester, did not learn any CAD or arduino code or anything else. The labs were pointless and we didn't do anything practical. We were later asked to complete a project that was not even complicated, however we were not prepared for it. We were not required to put the skills we picked up in class to the test, we had to look online, improvise, hope it would work. And the entire semester grade was that, as we had no other assignments.
